data.title: London’s blue plaque scheme set to be introduced across England
data.meta_description: Under government proposals, people will be able to nominate individuals and locations for blue plaques outside London
data.text:
The blue plaques that commemorate the famous former occupants of London’s buildings are set to be introduced across England under government proposals to be put in front of the House of Lords on Wednesday.

Since it was established in 1866 by the Society of Arts, the scheme has seen almost 1,000 blue roundels put on the exterior of buildings in the capital where luminaries from the worlds of science, the arts, philanthropy and politics once lived or worked.

To be eligible, an individual must have been dead for 20 years or passed the centenary of their birth, and must not be a fictional character.

Charles Dickens, Agatha Christie, Benjamin Franklin, Nancy Astor, Charles Darwin and Rosalind Franklin are among those celebrated by the plaques, which
